Issues.Title: Request: Placeholder support for the textbox control
Issues.Body:
This is a future feature request for the textbox control (and maybe others as well where this fits into) to have easy property support for a watermark / placeholder text. This is one of the most things you see in custom control WPF libraries. It should be easy to add to the source.

Please note that watermark also has been added to the winforms repo already https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/238 in case you may ask about the why. I could submit a PR but I'm not sure if that's too early as the WPF team may be too busy to work on the .NET Core 3 release for September?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Request: Placeholder support for the textbox control" (#1127)

Issues.Title: June Update for WPF on .NET Core 3.0
Issues.Body:
# June Update for WPF on .NET Core 3.0

In last month’s [update](https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/issues/738), we shared the exciting news that the team had open sourced 15 additional assemblies.  This month we continue to port the WPF code base to work on .NET Core and all of the latest bug fixes and code updates for Preview 7 are available via the [daily builds](https://github.com/dotnet/core-sdk/blob/master/README.md#installers-and-binaries).  The latest released version is Preview 6 and available via [this download page](https://dotnet.microsoft.com/download/dotnet-core/3.0).

The team has been getting better and better at operating in the open, we have improved our issue triage process with a goal of triaging new issues at least twice a week.   This will ensure that we identify issues that need to be solved for .NET Core 3.0 and also to assign all issues to a milestone. 

We have been working hard at fixing issues for 3.0 and porting additional functionality from .NET Framework.  You can review all [issues](https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/issues?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aclosed+closed%3A2019-05-23..2019-06-26+) and [PRs](https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/pulls?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=is%3Apr+is%3Aclosed+closed%3A2019-05-23..2019-06-26) that have been closed since last month's update.  

Here are a few callouts for issues resolved this month:

*  **Localization:** @ryalanms has been working on improving WPF's localization and fixing [localization issues](https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/issues/913).
* **Removing Deprecated Features:**   we have been working on cleaning up deprecated features, @ojhad has been working on removing code for a [deprecated security mode](https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/pull/1035)l and @vatsan-madhavan closed a PR for [removing XBAP code](https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/pull/1009).
* **Intellisense Support:**  @vatsan-madhavan has been doing some work on ensuring that [Intellisense works](https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/pull/979) for all Visual Studio users
* **Test Porting:** @miguep, @sambent and @arpitmathur have been working on porting feature tests and fixing DRTs.
* **Improving documentation and test infrastructure:**  @Stevenbrix has been working on improving the developer guide and on-boarding to [Helix's test infrastructure](https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/pull/888). 
* **Imrove Usability of WindowsDesktopSDK:**   @vatsan-madhavan did some work ([#1027](https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/pull/1027),[#3315](https://github.com/dotnet/sdk/pull/3315)) to improve the usability of WindowsDesktop SDK by adding warnings when UseWpf or UseWindowsForms are not set.  
* **API Compatibility Checks:**  @rladuca did [work](https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/pull/880) on [API Compatibility](https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/blob/master/Documentation/api-compat.md) in WPF, to set up and enable API Compat against .NET 4.8 reference assemblies, hand-crafted ref assemblies and their lib counterparts.
* **Application Compatibility Flags:**  We [ensured](https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/pull/787) that the Application Compatibility flags that were inherited in .NET Core from .NET Framework continue to work as before. The list and the respective default values in .NET Core are documented in this [sample](https://github.com/microsoft/WPF-Samples/pull/87/files#diff-367b1d34f8344ca7b58710a6b1d70a1a).


Thank again for your contributions and engagement.   If you have questions, suggestions, or concerns, please let us know.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "June Update for WPF on .NET Core 3.0" (#1113)

Issues.Title: packaging test updates and updates to packaging tests
Issues.Body:
I took advantage of this unique situation to give myself a clever little title ;)

This PR does a few things:
1. Updates our packaging to create a `Microsoft.DotNet.Wpf.DncEng.Test` package that contains our test infrastructure that compiles against `Microsoft.NETCore.App` instead of `Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App`. This should be a fairly temporary solution until we open source the infrastructure entirely. There will be an internal PR that consumes this, and then once that is done we can update this repo to consume it.
2. Adds a few of the packaging tests that don't have any special test content files and fixes them from the packaging refactor. The rest of the tests will be updated in the internal repo until we have time to go through OSS cleanup on them.

Fixes #1051 
Fixes #1052

Issues.Title: Using different TextFormattingModes with FlowDocument can sometimes use the incorrect mode.
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: any
* Windows version: Windows 10 1903
* Does the bug reproduce also in WPF for .NET Framework 4.8?: Yes

 <!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/blob/master/Documentation/issue-guide.md -->
 
 **Problem description:**

Using `TextOptions.SetTextFormattingMode()` on a `FlowDocument` or `RichTextBox` should use the specified mode when using different modes in the same application. 
 
 **Actual behavior:** <!-- callstack for crashes / exceptions -->

The actual mode used is somewhat random, and you cannot change it after it is set.
 
 **Expected behavior:**

The mode specified should be used.
 
 **Minimal repro:**

Create/use many FlowDocument (or RichTextBox) objects with different formatting modes. E.g.

``` 
var richText1 = new RichTextBox();
TextOptions.SetTextFormattingMode(richText1, TextFormattingMode.Ideal);
var richText2 = new RichTextBox();
TextOptions.SetTextFormattingMode(richText2, TextFormattingMode.Display);
```

I have tracked this down to a bug in [`PtsCache.AcquireContextCore`](https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/blob/8c7ab1592b6c70e732106aeabf58f215d4b71c22/src/Microsoft.DotNet.Wpf/src/PresentationFramework/MS/Internal/PtsHost/PtsCache.cs#L181), where it does not take the desired textFormattingMode into account when looking up an existing context to use from the cache.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Using different TextFormattingModes with FlowDocument can sometimes use the incorrect mode." (#1101)

Issues.Title: Update Microsoft.Dotnet.Arcade.Wpf.Sdk to accommodate changes to Microsoft.Build.Tasks.Git tasks
Issues.Body:
#### Update Microsoft.Dotnet.Arcade.Wpf.Sdk to accommodate changes to Microsoft.Build.Tasks.Git tasks

https://github.com/dotnet/sourcelink/pull/288/

WPF internal builds are failing with parameter not supported error: 

*##[error].packages\microsoft.dotnet.arcade.wpf.sdk\4.8.0-preview7.19324.12\tools\Packaging.targets(375,49): error MSB4064: (NETCORE_ENGINEERING_TELEMETRY=Build) The "Directory" parameter is not supported by the "Microsoft.Build.Tasks.Git.LocateRepository" task. Verify the parameter exists on the task, and it is a settable public instance property.*

*##[error].packages\microsoft.dotnet.arcade.wpf.sdk\4.8.0-preview7.19324.12\tools\Packaging.targets(375,5): error MSB4063: (NETCORE_ENGINEERING_TELEMETRY=Build) The "Microsoft.Build.Tasks.Git.LocateRepository" task could not be initialized with its input parameters.*

Fix `GenerateVersionFileWithRepositoryCommit` target and update .NET tools to include new Arcade SDK.
